repnme.cdata!:
Kosovo, Serbia, and Montenegro - Second
            Community Development Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Community
            Development Fund Project for Kosovo, Serbia, and Montenegro
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            project confirmed that social fund activities can provide a
            better quality of life for the poor, can be efficient
            mechanisms for constructing small-scale infrastructure, can
            build social capital, and have a visible, inclusive
            development impact. Indeed, these operations can serve as
            catalysts for a process in which citizens in targeted
            communities, especially in mixed and minority communities,
            gradually came together over time and participate in the
            design, implementation and monitoring of projects which
            respond to the common good of the community. An important
            lesson of this project is that the sustainability of
            community investments has significantly improved through the
            financial management training which resulted in
            municipalities preparing five-year financial plans which now
            provide line items for maintenance expenditures of public
            facilities. In addition, training in the areas of monitoring
            and supervision of micro-projects is equally critical. A
            critical aspect in this type of operation is the development
            of a comprehensive framework for stakeholder involvement and
            participation, in addition to strong institutional support
            from the project team, effective systems and procedures.
            Outreach and promotion, a community mapping and profiling
            exercise, and needs assessments are important elements to
            the success of this operation. Indeed, better communication
            between project committees, municipality authorities and
            beneficiaries also underline the importance of including an
            awareness raising component in this type of operation. The
            targeting of young people in this type of project, and
            particularly give the sensitive political situation in
            Kosovo, was of considerable importance because among
            conflict-affected areas, youth risks are the highest due to
            the combined conditions of conflict, poverty, and high
            levels of youth unemployment.

docna.cdata!:
Kosovo, Serbia, and Montenegro - Second
            Community Development Fund Project

Kosovo, Serbia, and Montenegro -
            Second Community Development Fund Project

repnme.cdata!: Building a new Kosovo - One village at a time

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            building a new Kosovo, one village at a time. The people of
            Podujevë were busy pulling their lives together from the
            ravages of conflict and the complications of Kosovo’s
            uncertain reality. The most immediate problem was the stench
            from the open-sewers and the diseases that brought with
            them. So the towns people got together and drew up plans to
            lay a sewage line along the main street. All villagers with
            cash to spare contributed to the project. For each small
            project, their partner was the Community Development Fund
            (CDF). The fund was set up in 1999 by the World Bank. So far
            it has provided grants to 320 projects all over Kosovo.
            Village committees pass project ideas to the municipal
            councils which must agree to provide their share before a
            proposal is submitted to the CDF. The CDF staff manage the
            finances of each project and train local civil servants to
            improve their performance. Contractors like it too because
            they are more likely to get paid in full and on time. A
            major strength of the fund, which focuses on local
            infrastructure, schools, and social services is the special
            relationship it has fostered between citizens and municipal
            authorities. Its success has attracted additional support
            from several governments like Austrians, Canadians, Dutch,
            and Swiss.

docna.cdata!: Building a new Kosovo - One village at a time

Building a new Kosovo - One
            village at a time

TF054421-CIDA COFINANCING GRANT FOR
            KOSOVO COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND II PROJECT,TFS54421-CANADIAN COFINANCING OF THE

25074415.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Rural development,Social protection and risk management,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
At the heart of the Balkans is Decan, a
            rural municipality in western Kosovo on the Albanian border.
            For centuries Decans inhabitants lived off the land, with
            almost three quarters of the workforce employed in
            agriculture. The war, however, severely disrupted economic
            activity. In the 1999 conflict, most of Decans inhabitants
            fled and almost three fifths of all houses were totally
            destroyed. Most of the Agro- Kombinat, the collective
            farming infrastructure, was severely damaged and a lot of
            private farming equipment disappeared. Poverty increased and
            unemployment, particularly among youth, rose dramatically.
            Basic infrastructure was lacking. The breakdown of social
            services worsened conditions. In these trying circumstances,
            the most vulnerable social groups - particularly the
            disabled - suffered the most. The case of Decan is
            representative of the challenges the World Bank faces in
            helping people rebuild their lives in Kosovo. Post-war
            reconstruction tends to focus primarily on emergency
            assistance. Yet a strong commitment to long-term,
            sustainable development is crucial for assistance to bear fruit.

repnme.cdata!:
Kosovo, Serbia and Montenegro - Second
            Community Development Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the proposed Community
            Development Fund II Project will be to: (i) Improve the
            quality, access, and availability of community
            infrastructure and services in poor and conflict-affected
            communities, and for the most vulnerable groups, including
            returnees; and (ii) Promote institutional capacity building
            at the community and municipal levels so as to improve the
            quality and sustainability of service delivery, and enhance
            greater stakeholder participation and empowerment in local
            development. This project has the following three
            components: Component 1) will finance on a grant basis,
            small-scale community works and services projects selected
            on a demand-driven basis with the active participation of
            community groups and local governments. The Community
            Infrastructure Sub-component will address the need for
            rehabilitation and construction of small-scale social and
            economic infrastructure at the local level through the
            financing of community investment micro-projects. The
            Community Social Services Sub-component will support
            community services programs targeted to address the needs of
            vulnerable and disadvantaged groups in Kosovo with a view to
            promote inter-community integration by actively engaging
            citizens in the development process of their communities.
            Component 2) will complement the community investment
            component, enabling local level institutions and community
            groups to address the needs and priorities for local
            development through a comprehensive capacity building
            program which would be consistent with current transference
            of responsibilities under the Mandate to establish
            substantial self-government. At the Micro-project level,
            institutional strengthening will focus on local governments,
            communities and contractors participating in community
            infrastructure and services micro-projects. At the local
            government level the project will focus on capacity building
            needs in municipalities with the aim of enhancing the
            understanding of municipal authorities of their potential
            role in facilitating and supporting community-based
            initiatives to address major priorities. Component 3) will
            support the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) covering
            operating costs such as acquisition of minor
            additional/replacements of office furniture and equipment,
            communications, local travel, utilities and publications,
            office rent, office supplies, fuel, internet service, bank
            commission charges, vehicle maintenance and repair, and
            Community Development Fund (CDF) staff salaries. It will
            also finance financial audits.

repnme.cdata!:
Kosovo, Serbia and Montenegro - Second
            Community Development Fund Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Community Development Fund
            Project will improve the quality of community
            infrastructure, and services in poor, and conflict-affected
            communities, and/or vulnerable groups, and, promote
            institutional capacity-building, and social capital
            formation. In view of the nature of this project, namely the
            infrastructure development aspects of its micro-projects for
            health and education facilities, water supply, wastewater
            sewage and small scale irrigation, and roads construction,
            this environmental assessment stipulates the following
            mitigation measures. To minimize soil erosion and
            contamination due to construction, and/or medical waste
            materials, regular control and cleaning of construction
            sites should be enforced, including the provision of
            adequate waste disposal services. Special attention should
            be given to drainage systems, with a proper disposal of oil
            and other hazardous materials, adequately disposed of,
            according to sanitary, and standard waste disposal
            regulations. Construction should be restricted to daytime
            hours, to prevent noise disturbances, and in addition, prior
            to construction, special attention should be given to site
            selection, to mitigate loss of natural vegetation (to be
            followed by re-vegetation practices), or sensitive species.
            Protection of historical/cultural sites, call for the
            immediate notification to the relevant authorities should
            archaeological finds occur. Specifically designed methods
            should be in place for the disposal of medical wastes.
            Regarding irrigation schemes, extension and training in crop
            selection, and agricultural technology should be provided,
            to include as well adequate drainage systems, and control of
            agrochemical uses.

docna.cdata!:
Kosovo, Serbia and Montenegro - Second
            Community Development Fund Project : environmental assessment
